subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Fwd: Foreign sounds (was Re: Maps in Quikscript)
msgSnippet: Sorry for late answer. Too much to do IRL! ... being, one might add, languages spoken in the British Isles. ... yes, though for actually writing Spanish #13
messageBody:
Sorry for late answer. Too much to do IRL!

Benjamin Bruce skrev:
> I would also note that Quickscript already has a couple of
> letters dedicated to foreign sounds (designed for Celtic
> languages in particular):

being, one might add, languages spoken in the British Isles.

> [x] and
> [K]. I have effectively used the former for transcribing
> Spanish names,

yes, though for actually writing Spanish #13 would probably
be a better choice, the [x] not really being quick to write.

> and the latter for names in the Aztec language Nahuatl
> (which has the affricate [tK]).

Did you use the reverse #24 for all of [tK], or did you
write it with #3 preposed? IIRC modern dialects have /K/
distinct from /tK/, but Classical Nahuatl hasn't.

I have used the reverse #24 "ll" for Italian and
Russian /L/, and
#21 for Italian and Russian /J/. This use of "ll" is not
really needed for Spanish, but handy if one wants to
indicate that a word is spelled with "ll" rather than "y" or
"hi". Of course /ts/ and /dz/ are #7 and #8!

It occurs to me that Spanish might use #14 to distinguish
"rr" from "r".

For Italian I used the vowel letters as 'long/short' pairs
as follows:

- #26 #27 = i
- #28 #29 = e
- #30 #31 = a
- #32 #33 = o
- #34 #35 = O
- #36 #37 = E
- #39 #40 = u

The actual use of these was twofold: I used the second in
each pair for a vowel followed by a double consonant or a
final stressed vowel, but the first followed by a single
consonant or final unstressed. A bit weird, but useful in
practice, since consonant length is distinctive in Italian,
but double consonants are hard to write in QS. Perhaps not
as useful in Spanish, although backing up to write a stress
mark is easily forgotten. Diphthongs I wrote with #17 #26
#18 as would be most convenient, except that "ie" was always
#26+36 and "uo" was #38 instead of the unwieldy
#18+34.


>
> While Quickscript is designed and well suited for writing
> English, it's entirely possible and useful to be able to
> use it for transcribing other languages as well.

Amen!

> -Benjamin Bruce
>

/BP
